posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked:
So, powering a robot using an extension cord/mains power. At a recent outreach event I noted that we are increasingly just running through our batterys and killing the old ones we have by over draining them. I was thinking it would be better if we could just plug the robot into the wall.

On first thought the biggest limitation I see is spikes current draw. Most wall outlets in the us run on a 15A breaker at 120v. So that is 1800 watts. FRC robots run with a nominal voltage of around 13v. So 1800w/13v=138.46A. So in theory that is fine for the 120A breaker we have in FRC but that is 120A under on constant load, in normal robot conditions we see currents draw much higher than that.

With running a robot for an outreach event in mind it seems that might be possible to get down to below the 138A limit with current limits set correctly. But I think there is a problem with how the motors react with putting power back into the system when using an AC->DC converter. But I could be wrong about that.

What do people think? Has anyone tried using mains power to power a robot? And if so how did you go about doing that?

link_counts.title: Using Extension Cord / Wall Power to Run Robot for Testing?

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
I’m going to go a different route:

Marine batteries, or 12V >18AH batteries. Mark for OUTREACH USE ONLY.

If you’re just running outreach, you could set up an extra-capacity battery so you don’t just blast through batteries. You would need some extra robot space, but it’s doable.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
If you’re working your robot as hard as match play at an outreach event, you’re probably doing something wrong.

Especially if there’s a cord connected to it.

Cheap Off grid solar setups will use a lead acid battery, solar battery charger, and inverter all directly connected to each other through the battery terminals. Solar charges the battery, battery runs the inverter, inverter runs your well pump or whatever.

I bet you could do fine on the same concept, a ~10A charger parallel to the robot battery, and significantly extend runtime.

The problem is that ~100A chargers get really really big and heavy.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
Running a robot continuously (i.e. enough batteries to always be operating) would toast the drive motors within an hour in the old days of brushed CIMs. I imagine that may still be a limitation.

I have on my desk right now a TUNS300F12, which is pretty much the most dense 12VDC power supply I’ve seen; 25A, about the volume of an Altoids tin. You could easily slap 6 of those in a battery-sized box with some heat sinking for 150A. They’re like 85% efficient so I think you’re still good on a 120V 15A circuit. I also just realized they’re $200 a pop . Definitely keep a battery in parallel, and this ignores the logistical issues of that 12/3 cable the robot needs now.

13v is too high as well, nobody is fielding robots with anything higher than a 12.8V battery after bleeding off the surface charge. The 120A breaker is basically a joke in the time scale of an FRC match. It does tell you that the robot is pulling less than 120A on average, as I’ve never tripped one even during long practice sessions. As long as you can feed in 120A on average, a battery in parallel with your wall power should never run out.

posts.name: evanperryg
posts.cooked:
You could easily slap 6 of those in a battery-sized box with some heat sinking for 150A

Do your homework before trying something like this. Hooking up a bunch of independent switch mode supplies in parallel with no further considerations can sometimes lead to some really nasty problems. Further reading: https://www.digikey.com/en/articles/properly-configure-parallel-power-supplies

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
I am assuming OP would look into that before dropping $1200 on DC power supplies.

The correct solution is more likely one of these bad boys , despite being twice the volume. Well… “correct” is a stretch.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
A couple of tips from making and using mains power units in FRC :

Put a Shottky or active rectifier on the output of your power supply and feed a 12V supercapacitor module.

Put a 12V incandescent auto clearance lamp across the supercapacitor.

Bonus points for an appropriate breaker…

Braking on brushless motors can push significant energy back and either make your dc power supply unhappy/shut down in protest/fry.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: That looks awesome! Do you mind sharing more info about what I am seeing here?

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked:
Weldingrod1:

Braking on brushless motors can push significant energy back and either make your dc power supply unhappy/shut down in protest/fry.

Do you think adding some parallel diodes to clamp the voltage to battery levels would be enough?

Now that I think about it, has anyone tried that in actual competition to protect a limelight or other sensitive devices? Would be pretty good to free up our VRM from that.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
You can’t clamp it with simple diodes.  You can do that with a solenoid because you know where the inductive kick comes from and you can put the diode after the switch.

You could build up an active zener with a serious power transistor that could do the clamping.  Using a diode and a significant capacitor is a better method if you are trying to kill the peak.  Add a resistor across the diode to keep the capacitor voltage near battery voltage when its not active.  A power zener or an active zener/clamp circuit across the capacitor would be smart too.  Though with normal capacitors is easy enough to buy them in 24 Volt rating Calculating the energy clipping capacity needed is probably do-able, but it depends on a LOT of things, many of which we only know roughly.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: Ideally I think you’d want something like this but sized for FRC motors: ODrive Regen Clamp – ODrive Robotics

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
On my unit I’m using an active rectifier module, also called an “ideal diode”.  Its got some smarts on it in addition to a normal diode AND a big mosfet.  Basically, when you first pass power through the diode, it charges a capacitor.  Then the smarts take that and turn on the mosfet, which drops the forward voltage across the diode to darn near zero.  The capacitor voltage drops slowly.  Once it gets too low, the mosfet drops out and the capacitor is re-charged by the diode voltage drop.  Here’s what I bought: https://www.ebay.com/itm/394881819726

There’s another version that has a ground terminal on it that is a “all the time” active rectifier.  BUT, it has more limitations that the one above.

A big-ol shottky rectifier would work fine too, but your 12v will be a bit less.; 11.9 Volts or so. Even a regular big-ol diode would be OK too, but you will get about 11.3 Volts on a 12V power supply.

Here’s the supercapacitor module I used.  Note that the balancing circuitry is CRITICAL for function, and you need to be super careful not to short these things.  They can deliver wire-melting currents! https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08CGXJY2J

Here’s the 83 Amp power supply its all based on.  We found out quickly that braking regeneration makes this sucker unhappy by itself…  Shuts down in protest.  For stuff with this kind of current output, remember that it can MELT undersized wires and foolishly applied tools! https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07HGQXW9V?th=1

The dumb filament 12V bulb is needed to make sure the output goes to zero when you turn it off.  Its also a good reminder that its ON.  Get it from your local auto parts place.  The frame ground is a PITA to work around, just so you know.  Might try to find something with two actual wires…

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Yes.

The power supplies that are meant to be paralleled have circuitry to force them to share the output current. The typical, off-the-shelf power supply will not have this feature. The tolerance on the output voltage is determined by the tolerance of the voltage reference in the controller chips. This is typically ±1% to ±5% so it is virtually guaranteed that the power supplies will not share the output current.

A coworker who thought he knew better wasted a lot of time on a system with 3 paralleled power supplies. They did not share the dynamic loads properly and caused all sorts of problems.

rich.varone:

Ideally I think you’d want something like this but sized for FRC motors: ODrive Regen Clamp – ODrive Robotics

Please note that the device linked is meant to work with an external resistor (see the 4 picture) connected to the R+ and R- terminals. There are calculations that must be done to determine the resistance value and power rating of the external resistor. Unfortunately, the calculators I am familiar with are all oriented to be used with AC induction motors. These resistors can get pretty big and will need adequate ventilation to dissipate the heat.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
This is a pretty major TLDR kinda reply…  I’ve had to do stuff like this professionally.

On the brake resistor side, there are three critical parameters: resistance, power rating, and energy rating.  Peak power rating is related to energy, so you may find that one listed.

O-Drive’s braking resistor sizing stuff is useful and worth a read.

With heat sink you need the peak resistor current less than 80 Amps; so R>0.15 Ohms.  That’s 960 Watts during a max power brake event.  You might THINK you need a 1kW resistor, but you don’t.  You only feed that resistor when you are braking!

What you DO need is one that will not fuse/fry at 80 Amps.  Wire wound resistors can handle 10-100x their long-term power levels for -short- times.  Wire wound is the key item here, NOT film of any sort.  So, it would’t be crazy to use four, 0.8 Ohm resistors in parallel.  That way if you fry one, you still have protection Current sense resistors are commonly around 0.1 Ohm; you could use four in a series parallel configuration and get a useful value.

Special resistors made to be braking resistors are designed for high peak and specified for energy rating.  Here’s an example.  $17 isn’t bad, but the resistor value is WAAAAY too high for 12V operation.  Its specified for 10X overload (800 Watts) for 10 -seconds-!  That’s 8 kilo Joules!  Yike! https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/drives_-a-_soft_starters/ac_variable_frequency_drives_(vfd)/braking_units_-a-_resistors/gs-br-080w200

You should also have some idea of how much energy you need to dissipate!  For a drive system, the 1/2 M V^2 kinetic energy of the robot will end up somewhere.  A decent fraction will end up heating the windings of the motor and heating the drive system.  You shouldn’t hope for more than maybe 10-15% to end up in the electronics.  The rest ends up in your pulse suppressor.  You need the voltage on the capacitor bank to NOT go above the voltage rating of both the capacitors AND that of the motor drivers.  So, one answer is a BIG capacitor bank that can hold the whole surge.  Expensive and nerve-wracking…  Having a way to dump some of that energy into a resistor pulls down the needed capacitor rating.

Knowing the potential regenerated energy will let you scope out how much power handling you need to design for.

One semi-silly answer is a stead load.  During normal operation its wasting power, but during a pulse the diode isolates the power supply so that the steady load is taking regenerated current.  Light bulbs are cheap resistors…  Its not going to take a LOT of energy, but its something.

Note that for a tethered robot, its probably not going to get anywhere near full speed on the drive system.  Flywheels and elevators, however, WILL get to full speed.

There are special resistors with actual Joules of energy ratings; I used some on a device designed to deliver 500 Amp pulses at 5kV.  Vaporize things power!  I had to limit the peak current to avoid frying the switching device, thus the massively parallel bank of non-inductive energy rated resistors.  Fun times!

1149.80 KB

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
I know I’ll be yelled at for this, but for continuous Robot running on a field, we add a “Y” connector to the robot side and hot swap batteries.  This way the robot acts like the robot.  For a bench top setup, a battery in parallel with a charger.

Super cheap. Super easy.

Contrary to popular opinion, this happens a lot in the real world, like every time a trailer equipped with an AUX/Braking battery is plugged into a tow vehicle, 2 dissimilar batteries are connected in parallel.

I would only do this with lead acids.  They are forgiving.
